page.title: 04OPEN AREAS AND FIELDS.
page.content: Most of the fields are under arable crop production or intensive grass and are sprayed with herbicides to keep them free from weeds, but around their headlands where the spray hasn't penetrated there is an abundance of wild plants including cleavers, may-weeds, poppies, chickweed and buttercups. In the open spaces and less intensive farmland ribwort, thistles, docks, spurge and tansy predominate. Bird-life abounds: pheasants and partridges, larks overhead, magpies, blackbirds and jays, while kestrels hover, searching for prey. Ears of wheat are colonised by the grain aphid which, in turn, attracts ladybirds and hover-flies. A variety of footpaths and tracks, fairly well signposted, enable the walker to enjoy the countryside.
